text: Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success. Doctor: Yes. It’s um you know the ones that we have just for prostate doesn’t allow people who’ve had chemo, but we have a couple more in the phase one group that potentially will. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’re gonna tap into those. There’s also um this new trial that’s looking at PSMA that I’m quite interested in. Just a matter of if we have a slot or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It just opened, it just opened. Patient: And what is a PSMA? Doctor: That’s literally like a target. It’s like a PSA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s a target on your cells and we try to go after it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That sounds like fun. Patient: Wow.

text: Patient: Positive as in good news? Or – Doctor: No, that you’ve got a mutation. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, so, it’s kinda letting the genie out of the bottle a little bit once I tell you the results. Because, it has, you know, significance for your family. Family Member: And that’s what I was going to ask you. Patient: Hey! I want to know. Doctor: Okay. So, there’s a gene called BRCA2 which is – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Associated with prostate and breast cancer. I’ll write it down for you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Um, that your – you have a mutation that you’ve inherited. What does that mean? Um. Well, we know that BRCA2 can be, um, a predisposition to getting prostate cancer. Patient: Well, I should tell you that -- I think it happened since I saw you – my brother was diagnosed.

text: Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And then no pain. So, you’re the asymptomatic person Patient: Okay. Gotch ya. Doctor: and like uh, I got cancer, what, oh, perfect Provenge candidate. text: Family Member: But then that means they won’t prick you every time for the blood draw. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I stay all day downtown or midtown? Family Member: And why are they, why do they, that’s interesting. Doctor: Well because they want to see how the levels of the drug, how long it takes for it to clear and things like that. So frankly along with the Xtandi there are not – this is sort of the first study of combining it with either Xtandi or Zytega and you know the single agent studies they kind of have they know what to expect. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But in combination they need to see how the drug levels behave. Patient: How many days will I have to be there? Doctor: I think there are two long days, but you’ll have the full schedule of how often you have to come in. Family Member: So this is a different clinical trial. Is it a clinical trial? Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
